title: 107_s203
content: The "Teacher Support Act of 2001" allows above-the-line deduction for qualified professional development expenses of elementary and secondary school teachers under section 222 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Teacher Support Act of 2001" allows eligible teachers to deduct qualified professional development expenses, including tuition, fees, books, supplies, equipment, and transportation for qualified courses of instruction. The "Teacher Support Act of 2001" allows eligible teachers to deduct professional development expenses related to curriculum, academic subjects, teaching different learning styles, disabilities, and state standards. The "Teacher Support Act of 2001" allows eligible teachers to deduct professional development expenses related to curriculum, academic subjects, teaching different learning styles, disabilities, and children with special learning needs. The professional development must be tied to challenging State or local content standards, student performance standards, and effective strategies for increasing student academic achievement. The "Teacher Support Act of 2001" allows eligible teachers to deduct professional development expenses tied to increasing student academic achievement and teaching skills. The professional development must have a lasting impact on the teacher's performance in the classroom. The "Teacher Support Act of 2001" allows eligible teachers to deduct professional development expenses that are part of a certified program approved by the local educational agency. The term 'local educational agency' is defined in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The term 'eligible teacher' refers to a kindergarten through grade 12 classroom teacher or aide who works at least 720 hours during a school year. No other deduction or credit is allowed for the same expenses, and the deduction is coordinated with exclusions. The amendment allows a deduction for qualified professional development expenses that exceed certain exclusions under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This deduction is added to the computation of adjusted gross income, and a conforming amendment is made to the table of sections. The amendment provides a credit to elementary and secondary school teachers who purchase classroom materials. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years starting after December 31, 2000. The amendment allows eligible teachers to claim a tax credit for qualified elementary and secondary education expenses up to $100. Eligible teachers include kindergarten through grade 12 classroom teachers, instructors, counselors, aides, or principals on a full-time basis. Qualified expenses cover books and supplies. The tax credit allows eligible teachers to claim education expenses for books, supplies, computer equipment, and other materials used in the classroom. The credit does not allow double benefits and cannot exceed certain limits. The tax credit for eligible teachers allows them to claim education expenses for classroom materials. A taxpayer may elect to have this credit not apply for any taxable year. The tax credit for eligible teachers allows them to claim education expenses for classroom materials, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000.
